PersA-FL: Personalized Asynchronous Federated Learning

\nameMohammad Taha Toghania, Soomin Leeb, C√©sar A. Uribea This work was partly done while MTT interning at Yahoo! Research. Part of this material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grants #2211815 and #2213568. Corresponding Author‚Äôs Email: mttoghani@rice.edu aDepartment of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rice University, Houston, TX, USA bYahoo! Research, Sunnyvale, California, USA
Abstract

We study the personalized federated learning problem under asynchronous updates. In this problem, each client seeks to obtain a personalized model that simultaneously outperforms local and global models. We consider two optimization-based frameworks for personalization: (i) Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) and (ii) Moreau Envelope (ME). MAML involves learning a joint model adapted for each client through fine-tuning, whereas ME requires a bi-level optimization problem with implicit gradients to enforce personalization via regularized losses. We focus on improving the scalability of personalized federated learning by removing the synchronous communication assumption. Moreover, we extend the studied function class by removing boundedness assumptions on the gradient norm. Our main technical contribution is a unified proof for asynchronous federated learning with bounded staleness that we apply to MAML and ME personalization frameworks. For the smooth and non-convex functions class, we show the convergence of our method to a first-order stationary point. We illustrate the performance of our method and its tolerance to staleness through experiments for classification tasks over heterogeneous datasets.

keywords:
Federated Learning; Personalization; Asynchronous Communication; Heterogeneous Data; Distributed Optimization; Staleness.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is designed to facilitate distributed training of machine learning models across devices by exploiting the data and computation power available to them [38]. A major benefit of FL is its ability to allow training models on data distributed across multiple devices without centralization. This is particularly beneficial in situations with limited sensitive data [32, 33] where clients are reluctant to share their private data. At the same time, it is known that training over a larger set of data points improves the quality of the obtained model [68]. In such scenarios, FL enjoys the power of collaborative learning without relocating the data from its original source [32]. Nevertheless, FL poses challenges such as data heterogeneity (statistical diversity among clients) [34, 17, 11, 42], fairness [14, 43], privacy [24, 69, 30, 55], unreliable communication [60, 64], and staleness [70, 3, 44, 53].

The common underlying assumption that determines the superiority of FL to individual local training is that the data points of all clients are coming from the same distribution, i.e., homogeneous data across clients. Consequently, FL can improve the quality of empirical loss minimization when data available on each device is limited; otherwise, each client may obtain a proper model without collaboration or communication with others. Therefore, FL111We refer to Federated Learning with no personalization as FL. results in a common global model with better generalization across clients [46] compared to individual training. In heterogeneous data setups where clients hold samples from non-identical data distributions, a common (global) model may perform poorly on the local data points of each client. For instance, consider the next word prediction task on a smart keyboard [28], where each client has a unique writing style or emphasis on the vocabulary domain. In this example, the corresponding mobile application is supposed to suggest a set of words that will likely be selected as the next word in the sentence. This scenario clearly states a case with a heterogeneous data setup with a limited sample on each client‚Äôs device. Thus, if each client trains a model independently, without collaboration with the other clients, the model will likely perform poorly on the new data due to sample limitation. Hence, the question arises about what will occur if the clients hold data samples from similar (but not identical) distributions.

In FL with heterogeneous data, an ideal scenario is to learn a globally common model easily adaptable to local data on each client, i.e., model fusion. This approach is known as Personalized Federated Learning (PFL), which strives to exploit both the shared and unshared information from the data of all clients. A solution to the model fusion in PFL is to apply transfer learning [73, 12] (e.g., fine-tuning) on a jointly trained model under FL. Interestingly, the centralized version of this problem has been extensively studied in Meta-Learning [66] and Multi-Task Learning [50], where the goal is to obtain a meta (global) model that with (potentially) minimal adaptation performs well on multiple tasks. Particularly, Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) [21, 56] proposes an optimization-based formulation that aims to find an initial meta-model with proper performance after applying one or a few steps of (stochastic) gradient descent. The key property of MAML is its ability to gauge fine-tuning during the learning process. Multiple studies have been conducted on the convergence and generalization of MAML [16, 31, 22, 18, 19, 8] for various problems and setups. Fallah et¬†al. [17] suggest the MAML formulation as a potential solution for PFL, and propose Per-FedAvg algorithm for collaborative learning with MAML personalized cost function. Dinh et¬†al. [13] present pFedMe algorithm for PFL via adopting a different formulation for personalization, namely Moreau Envelopes (ME). The proposed algorithm is a joint bi-level optimization problem with personalized parameters which are regularized to be close to the global model. We will elaborate on these two formulations (MAML & ME) in Section 2. Additionally, several recent works have approached PFL mainly through optimization-based [26, 45, 64, 27, 29, 46, 72, 20, 10, 5, 23], or structure-based [9, 65, 59] techniques.

Scalability to large-scale setups with potentially many clients is another major challenge for FL. The proposed algorithms in this scheme, mostly require synchronous communications between the server and clients [47, 38, 23, 10, 43, 17, 13]. Such constraints impose considerable delays on the learning progress, since increasing the concurrency in synchronous updates decreases the training speed and quality. For example, limited communication bandwidth, computation power, and communication failures incur large delays in the training process. In cross-device FL, devices are naturally prone to update and communicate models under less restrictive rules, whereas clients may apply updates in an asynchronous fashion, i.e., staleness. Hogwild! [52] is one of the first efforts to model asynchrony in distributed setup with delayed updates. Multiple works have studied asynchronous training under different setups and assumptions [1, 49, 6, 53, 44, 4, 15]. Specifically, some recent seminal works have studied the convergence of asynchronous SGD-based methods, and show their convergence under certain assumptions on maximum or average delay [2, 61, 37, 48].222Mishchenko et¬†al. [48] studies the convergence of distributed optimization for homogeneous strongly convex and smooth functions with no assumptions on maximum delay, i.e., unbounded staleness. In decentralized setups, Hadjicostis et¬†al. [25] propose a consensus algorithm called running-sum, which is robust to message losses. Furthermore, Olshevsky et¬†al. [54] present a more general framework with robustness to asynchrony, message losses, and delays for both consensus and optimization problems [60, 64]. More closely, FL under stale updates has been thoroughly studied in [70, 51, 3, 57, 40, 65]. Particularly, Tziotis et¬†al. [65] studies the existence of stragglers in PFL via shared representations, i.e., system and data heterogeneity in structure-based personalization.

The main contribution of paper [51] is on the server algorithm, where this paper proposes a more secure and robust algorithm by aggregating a buffer of asynchronous updates within a secure channel prior to sending them to the server. Whereas, our work focuses on scalability and personalization via asynchronous communication and learning personalized models.

In this work, we study the PFL problem under asynchronous communications to improve training concurrency, performance, and efficiency. We propose the PersA-FL algorithm, a novel personalized & asynchronous method that jointly addresses the heterogeneity and staleness in FL. We develop a technique based on asynchronous updates to resolve the communication bottleneck imposed by synchronized learning in PFL, where we improve the training scalability and performance. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study on the intersection of staleness and personalization through the lens of optimization-based techniques. We summarize our contributions as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Through the integration of two personalization formulations, MAML & ME, we propose PersA-FL, an algorithm that allows personalized federated learning under asynchronous communications between the server and clients. Our proposed method consists of two algorithms from the perspectives of the server and clients. We present the client algorithm under three different options for the local updates, each addressing a separate formulation, (A) FedAsync, (B) PersA-FL-MAML, and (C) PersA-FL-ME.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We present a new convergence analysis for Asynchronous Federated Learning (FedAsync) under smooth non-convex cost functions by removing the boundedness assumption from the gradient norm. Our analysis assumes bounded variance of stochasticity and heterogeneity, and bounded maximum delay. Hence, we improve the existing theory by extending the result to a broader function class, i.e., unbounded gradient norm.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We show the convergence rate of PersA-FL-MAML based on the maximum delay and personalization budget under the same assumptions as Fallah et¬†al. [17].333Besides the assumptions for FedAsync, seminal works [17, 22, 56] assume second-order Lipschitzness, bounded variance, and bounded gradient in the analysis of MAML cost functions. We highlight the impact of batch size in the biased stochastic estimation of the full gradients for the MAML cost. We present the communication and sample complexity to find an ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon first-order stationary point for the proposed algorithm.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We prove the convergence of PersA-FL-ME with no boundedness assumption on the gradient norm. We discuss the connection of convergence rate to the gradient estimation error and level of personalization. Compared to [13], we show an explicit dependence of convergence rate to the estimation error. Moreover, we relax the heterogeneity assumption in [13] allowing bounded population diversity instead of uniformly bounded heterogeneity. We determine the communication and local inexact solver complexity to find an ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon first-order stationary point for this method.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We present numerical experiments evaluating our proposed algorithm on heterogeneous MNIST and CIFAR10 with unbalanced distributions across the clients. We illustrate the advantages of our method in terms of performance and scalability to varying delays in setups with heterogeneity.

Table 1 illustrates the properties of our proposed method and provides a comparison between our algorithm and underlying analysis with related seminal works. As shown in this table, building upon the results in [17, 13], we extend the capability of FL to staleness. Table 1 also contains the convergence results for our proposed algorithm, which we will discuss in more details in Section 4.

The main difference between our method and the works in [70, 51] mainly lies in the client algorithm, where we consider three options (A, B, and C) for updating the parameters locally. Option A is similar to the client algorithm in [70, 51], but we improve the theoretical convergence results by removing the assumption on bounded gradients for this setup. Option B and Option C, along with the server algorithm are novel methods for personalized asynchronous federated learning. Nguyen et¬†al. [51] characterize the server algorithm with a secure and robust update aggregation and [63] enhances its theoretical properties. Study of secure aggregation on the server side remains as a future direction for this work.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce the PFL setup and discuss the asynchronous communication framework between the server and clients. In Section 3, we describe our algorithm, PersA-FL, for PFL under staleness. In Section 4, we state the convergence result for our proposed algorithm along with the underlying assumptions and technical lemmas. We present the numerical experiments in Section 5. We finally end by concluding remarks in Section 6.

2 Problem Setup & Background

In this section, we first present the formal problem setup for FL [47], as well as the personalization formulations in MAML [17] and ME [13]. Then, we discuss the underlying communication setting under asynchronous updates.

2.1 Federated Learning Problem Setup

We consider a set of nùëõn clients and one server, where each client i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n] holds a private function fi:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, and the goal is to collaboratively obtain a model w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d} that minimizes the local cost functions on average, as follows:

minw‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°f‚Äã(w)‚âî1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nfi‚Äã(w),withfi‚Äã(w)‚âîùîºŒûi‚àºpi‚Äã[‚Ñìi‚Äã(w,Œûi)],formulae-sequence‚âîsubscriptùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëùëìùë§1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëìùëñùë§with‚âîsubscriptùëìùëñùë§subscriptùîºsimilar-tosubscriptŒûùëñsubscriptùëùùëñdelimited-[]subscript‚Ñìùëñùë§subscriptŒûùëñ\displaystyle\begin{split}\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(w)&\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(w),\\ \text{with}\quad f_{i}(w)&\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\Xi_{i}\sim p_{i}}[\ell_{i}(w,\Xi_{i})],\end{split} (1)

where ‚Ñìi:‚Ñùd√óùíÆi‚Üí‚Ñù:subscript‚Ñìùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚ÑùùëësubscriptùíÆùëñ‚Ñù\ell_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{S}_{i}\to\mathbb{R} is a cost function that determines the prediction error of some model w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d} over a single data point Œæi‚ààùíÆisubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùíÆùëñ\xi_{i}\in\mathcal{S}_{i} on client iùëñi, where Œæisubscriptùúâùëñ\xi_{i} is a realization of Œûi‚àºpisimilar-tosubscriptŒûùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ\Xi_{i}\sim p_{i}, i.e., pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} is the client iùëñi‚Äôs data distribution over ùíÆisubscriptùíÆùëñ\mathcal{S}_{i}, for i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n]. In the above definition, fi‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùëìùëñ‚ãÖf_{i}(\cdot) is the local cost function of client iùëñi, and f‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëì‚ãÖf(\cdot) denotes the global cost function, i.e., average loss. For instance, in a supervised learning setup with ùíµi‚âîùí≥i√óùí¥i‚âîsubscriptùíµùëñsubscriptùí≥ùëñsubscriptùí¥ùëñ\mathcal{Z}_{i}\coloneqq\mathcal{X}_{i}\times\mathcal{Y}_{i}, we have ‚Ñìi‚Äã(w,Œæi)subscript‚Ñìùëñùë§subscriptùúâùëñ\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i}) as the prediction cost of some learning model parameterized by wùë§w for sample Œæi=(x,y)subscriptùúâùëñùë•ùë¶\xi_{i}=(x,y), where x‚ààùí≥iùë•subscriptùí≥ùëñx\in\mathcal{X}_{i} and y‚ààùí¥iùë¶subscriptùí¥ùëñy\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}. Let ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i} be a data batch with samples independently drawn from the distribution pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}. Then, the unbiased stochastic cost associated with data batch ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i} can be denoted as follows:

f~i‚Äã(w,ùíüi)subscript~ùëìùëñùë§subscriptùíüùëñ\displaystyle\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i}) ‚âî1|ùíüi|‚Äã‚àëŒæi‚ààùíüi‚Ñìi‚Äã(w,Œæi),‚âîabsent1subscriptùíüùëñsubscriptsubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùíüùëñsubscript‚Ñìùëñùë§subscriptùúâùëñ\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{i}|}\sum\limits_{\xi_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{i}}\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i}), (2)

where for simplicity, we assume that the size of all batches is larger than bùëèb. Then, according to the above definition, we can immediately infer that

ùîºpi‚Äã[f~i‚Äã(w,ùíüi)]=fi‚Äã(w),ùîºpi‚Äã[‚àáf~i‚Äã(w,ùíüi)]=‚àáfi‚Äã(w),ùîºpi‚Äã[‚àá2f~i‚Äã(w,ùíüi)]=‚àá2fi‚Äã(w).formulae-sequencesubscriptùîºsubscriptùëùùëñdelimited-[]subscript~ùëìùëñùë§subscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùëìùëñùë§formulae-sequencesubscriptùîºsubscriptùëùùëñdelimited-[]‚àásubscript~ùëìùëñùë§subscriptùíüùëñ‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§subscriptùîºsubscriptùëùùëñdelimited-[]superscript‚àá2subscript~ùëìùëñùë§subscriptùíüùëñsuperscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñùë§\displaystyle\begin{split}\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})\right]&=f_{i}(w),\\ \mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})\right]&=\nabla f_{i}(w),\\ \mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\nabla^{2}\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})\right]&=\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w).\end{split} (3)

Several works have been proposed to solve (1) as a union of local and global optimization steps. For instance, FedAvg [47] suggests an iterative algorithm wherein at each round t‚â•0ùë°0t\geq 0, (i) server transmits its current parameter wtsuperscriptùë§ùë°w^{t} to a subset of the clients, (ii) each selected client updates the parameter locally, by applying QùëÑQ sequential rounds of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) with respect to its local cost function, then (iii) the selected clients send back their local parameter to the server, and finally, (iv) the server aggregates the so-called local parameters to obtain a new global parameter wt+1superscriptùë§ùë°1w^{t+1}. As a result, clients minimize the average loss in (1) with less communication cost, i.e., fewer global rounds. Note that the underlying assumption for methods such as FedAvg is the possibility of synchronized communications between the selected clients and the server. The left chart in Figure 1 represents the communication and update schedule for FedAvg. The performance of FL-based methods depends on the similarity of distributions ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i}, thus, cases with heterogeneous datasets slow down the convergence. Karimireddy et¬†al. [34] and [11] the effect of heterogeneity in the convergence speed. A solution of (1) is a common model for all the clients; hence no adaptation or fusion to each client‚Äôs data. Next, we elaborate on the personalization concept and discuss two alternative problem formulations for (1).

2.2 Personalized Federated Learning

In the previous section, we explained how a solution to (1) performs well when the data is homogeneous, and the goal is to obtain a shared model. On the one hand, using a single common model, with no adaptation to each client, does not necessarily lead to a proper performance when dealing with heterogeneous datasets. On the other hand, when the data distributions of different clients share some similarities, e.g., bounded variance in their heterogeneity, and the number of data points on each client is limited, joint training with fusion improves the performance compared to individual locally trained models or FL. Therefore, learning a shared model with little fine-tuning, e.g., a few steps of SGD with respect to the local cost, may result in a proper personalized model.

Fallah et¬†al. [17] proposed Per-FedAvg algorithm, which modifies the training loss function by taking advantage of the fact that fine-tuning will occur after training. The MAML formulation assumes a limited computational budget for personalization (fine-tuning) at each client. It then offers to look for an initial (global) parameter that performs well after it is updated with one or a few steps of SGD. In other words, [17] define the MAML loss function for PFL as follows:

minw‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°F(b)‚Äã(w)‚âî1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nFi(b)‚Äã(w),withFi(b)‚Äã(w)‚âîfi‚Äã(w‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(w)),formulae-sequence‚âîsubscriptùë§superscript‚Ñùùëësuperscriptùêπùëèùë§1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë§with‚âîsubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë§subscriptùëìùëñùë§ùõº‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§\displaystyle\begin{split}\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F^{(b)}(w)&\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}F^{(b)}_{i}(w),\\ \text{with}\quad F^{(b)}_{i}(w)&\coloneqq f_{i}(w-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(w)),\end{split} (4)

where Œ±‚â•0ùõº0\alpha\geq 0 is the MAML personalization stepsize. Solving (4) yields a global (meta) model that can be used to create a personalized model by applying one step of gradient descent with respect to individual loss functions. The degree of fine-tuning determines the personalization budget, which often controls the trade-off between having a local (personalized) or generic model, i.e., exploiting the shared and local knowledge simultaneously. In Problem (4), stepsize Œ±ùõº\alpha determines the personalization budget, where Œ±=0ùõº0\alpha=0 implies FL in Problem (1). See [31, 64, 18] for the study of multi-step MAML. In a nutshell, Per-FedAvg proposes to minimize F(b)‚Äã(w)superscriptùêπùëèùë§F^{(b)}(w) via a similar paradigm as FedAvg. Hence, each client iùëñi computes the personalized gradient of its MAML cost in (4), which can be written as follows:

‚àáFi(b)‚Äã(w)=[I‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àá2fi‚Äã(w)]‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(w‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(w)),‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë§delimited-[]ùêºùõºsuperscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñùë§‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§ùõº‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§\displaystyle\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)=\left[I{-}\alpha\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)\right]\nabla f_{i}\left(w{-}\alpha\nabla f_{i}(w)\right), (5)

where in Per-FedAvg, the authors propose to compute a biased estimation of (5) using stochastic gradients/Hessian. We will elaborate on the stochastic approximation in Section 3.

On a separate note, one of the major challenges in Per-FedAvg is the computation of second-order information such as Hessian for large-scale models (large dùëëd). However, as proposed by [17], one can skip the Hessian in the gradient formulation (FO-MAML) or approximate it with first-order information (HF-MAML) [16].

As an alternative option to MAML formulation in (4), Dinh et¬†al. [13] suggest solving the following optimization problem:

minw‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°F(c)‚Äã(w)‚âî1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nFi(c)‚Äã(w),withFi(c)‚Äã(w)‚âîminŒ∏i‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°[fi‚Äã(Œ∏i)+Œª2‚Äã‚ÄñŒ∏i‚àíw‚Äñ2],formulae-sequence‚âîsubscriptùë§superscript‚Ñùùëësuperscriptùêπùëêùë§1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñùë§with‚âîsubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñùë§subscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñsuperscript‚ÑùùëësubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùúÉùëñùúÜ2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÉùëñùë§2\displaystyle\begin{split}\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F^{(c)}(w)&\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}F^{(c)}_{i}(w),\\ \text{with}\quad F^{(c)}_{i}(w)&\coloneqq\min_{\theta_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left[f_{i}(\theta_{i})+\frac{\lambda}{2}{\left\|\theta_{i}-w\right\|}^{2}\right],\end{split} (6)

where each function Fi(c)‚Äã(w)subscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñùë§F^{(c)}_{i}(w) is a local cost of personalized parameter Œ∏i‚àà‚ÑùdsubscriptùúÉùëñsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\theta_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} by using the Moreau Envelope as a regularized loss function, and parameter Œª‚â•0ùúÜ0\lambda\geq 0 determines the degree of personalization. In this setup, Œª=0ùúÜ0\lambda=0 is equivalent to local training with no collaboration and as Œª‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùúÜ\lambda\to\infty, the formulation in (6) converges to FL in (1) with no personalization which is similar to the case in (4) with Œ±=0ùõº0\alpha=0. For non-extreme values of ŒªùúÜ\lambda, the clients jointly learn a global model wùë§w and personalized parameters Œ∏isubscriptùúÉùëñ\theta_{i}, which are regularized to remain close to wùë§w. Note that the gradient of Fi(c)‚Äã(w)subscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñùë§F^{(c)}_{i}(w) can be written as follows (please check out Appendix C to see the proof):

‚àáFi(c)‚Äã(w)‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñùë§\displaystyle\nabla F^{(c)}_{i}(w) =Œª‚Äã(w‚àíŒ∏^i‚Äã(w)),absentùúÜùë§subscript^ùúÉùëñùë§\displaystyle=\lambda\left(w-\hat{\theta}_{i}(w)\right), (7)
withŒ∏^i‚Äã(w)‚âî‚âîwithsubscript^ùúÉùëñùë§absent\displaystyle\text{with}\quad\hat{\theta}_{i}(w)\coloneqq arg‚ÄãminŒ∏i‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°[fi‚Äã(Œ∏i)+Œª2‚Äã‚ÄñŒ∏i‚àíw‚Äñ2],subscriptargminsubscriptùúÉùëñsuperscript‚ÑùùëësubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùúÉùëñùúÜ2superscriptnormsubscriptùúÉùëñùë§2\displaystyle\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left[f_{i}(\theta_{i})+\frac{\lambda}{2}{\left\|\theta_{i}-w\right\|}^{2}\right], (8)

where for large ŒªùúÜ\lambda, Œ∏^i‚Äã(w)subscript^ùúÉùëñùë§\hat{\theta}_{i}(w) is the exact solution to an optimization problem. Therefore, solving (6) through a similar approach to FedAvg or Per-FedAvg, itself requires minimizing Problem (8) which is potentially intractable. Dinh et¬†al. [13] propose a bi-level optimization algorithm called pFedMe, to minimize the optimization problem in (6) by alternating minimization over Œ∏isubscriptùúÉùëñ\theta_{i} and wùë§w. The main idea behind pFedMe is to integrating the computation of an inexact solution to (8) inside an FL-type method. We will explain and use this inexact approximation in the presentation of our method (Option C) in Section 3.

2.3 Asynchronous vs Synchronous Schedule

So far, we have discussed the three different formulations for collaborative learning that we will consider in our method. As we described the FedAvg algorithm in Subsection 2.1, at each round tùë°t, the parameter wtsuperscriptùë§ùë°w^{t}, which is the most recent version of the global parameter in the server, will be sent to a subset of the clients. Then, the server halts the training process until all selected clients receive this parameter, perform local updates, and transmit their updates back to the server. This synchronization procedure restricts the algorithm flow to the slowest client at each round. Nevertheless, asynchronous updates and communications can be described in this described framework.

Let us provide a comparison using the example in Figure 1 which illustrates the communication and update schedule for synchronous (left) & asynchronous (right) aggregations for n=5ùëõ5n=5 clients in FL with Q=3ùëÑ3Q=3 local updates. As shown in this Figure, for every update at the server-lever under synchronized updates (left figure), the server has to wait for all the selected clients. Nevertheless, these clients build their local updates based on the recent version of the server‚Äôs parameter. On the contrary, in the asynchronous scenario (right figure), the server updates the global parameter once it receives a new update from some client. The main challenge for the asynchronous setup is the staleness between download and upload time from/to the server. We design PersA-FL based on the second communication scenario.

3 Algorithm: FedAsync & PersA-FL

In this section, by integrating the problem formulations in (1), (4), and (6) into a united format, we propose Algorithms 1 & 2 to solve these problems under three different update choices at the client-level. We present our method through two different perspectives, (i) server and (ii) client.

‚ãÑ‚ãÑ\diamond Server Algorithm: Let us denote w0‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptùë§0superscript‚Ñùùëëw^{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} as the initial parameter at the server, where the objective is to minimize the cost function in either (1), (4), or (6). Each client i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n] may communicate with the server when the underlying connection is stable. Clients may request to download the server‚Äôs parameters at any time, and the server will send the most recent model after receiving the request. All underlying delays for the communications between the server and clients are modeled as download and upload delays. We consider variable tùë°t as a counter for the updates at the server level. Algorithm 1 represents the server updates in PersA-FL. The server performs an iterative algorithm where at each round t‚â•0ùë°0t\geq 0, remains on hold until receives an update Œîit‚àà‚ÑùdsubscriptŒîsubscriptùëñùë°superscript‚Ñùùëë\Delta_{i_{t}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} from some client it‚àà[n]subscriptùëñùë°delimited-[]ùëõi_{t}\in[n]. After receiving the update from client itsubscriptùëñùë°i_{t}, the server updates its parameter according to Step 4 of Algorithm 1, where Œ≤‚â•0ùõΩ0\beta\geq 0 is the server stepsize.

Now, we are ready to present the client algorithm. Before starting, note that we drop the time index from the iterates of the client algorithm for clarity of exposition.

‚ãÑ‚ãÑ\diamond Client Algorithm: Let us explain the operations of iùëñi-th client using the pseudo code in Algorithm 2. Client iùëñi repeats an iterative procedure which is composed of three phases, (i) downloading the most up-to-date model from the server as in Step 3, (ii) performing QùëÑQ local updates starting from the parameters of the downloaded model with respect to the cost function of the underlying problem, (1), (4), or (6), as in Steps 5-16, and (iii) uploading the sum of updates on the server as in Step 18. Note that Œ∑‚â•0ùúÇ0\eta\geq 0 is the local stepsize, a hyperparameter. The main idea for the local updates is to perform QùëÑQ sequential SGD steps on the local cost. Below, we list our stochastic estimation for the full gradients of each loss function introduced in Section 2:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Option A: This option intends to minimize (1). Therefore, for each client iùëñi at each local round qùëûq, we sample an independent data batch from pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} and compute an unbiased estimation of the loss as in (2).

  • ‚Ä¢

    Option B: By performing this option, we aim to minimize the MAML cost function in (4). As we saw in Section 2, the full gradient can be computed according to (5). Following [17], we sample three data batches to compute a biased estimation of (5) as follows:

    ‚àáF~i(b)‚Äã(w,ùíüi‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,ùíüi‚Ä≤,ùíüi)=[I‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àá2f~i‚Äã(w,ùíüi‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)]‚Äã‚àáf~i‚Äã(w‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àáf~i‚Äã(w,ùíüi‚Ä≤),ùíüi).‚àásubscriptsuperscript~ùêπùëèùëñùë§superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùíüùëñdelimited-[]ùêºùõºsuperscript‚àá2subscript~ùëìùëñùë§superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚àásubscript~ùëìùëñùë§ùõº‚àásubscript~ùëìùëñùë§superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùíüùëñ\displaystyle\nabla\tilde{F}^{(b)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\prime\prime},\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}_{i})=\left[I{-}\alpha\nabla^{2}\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\prime\prime})\right]\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}\left(w{-}\alpha\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\prime}),\mathcal{D}_{i}\right). (9)

    We will discuss the variance and bias of this estimator in Subsection 4.2

  • ‚Ä¢

    Option C: Finally, we invoke this option to minimize the ME personalized loss in (6). As we mentioned earlier, the full gradient of this cost is (7), where for a fixed wùë§w, we may obtain Œ∏^i‚Äã(w)subscript^ùúÉùëñùë§\hat{\theta}_{i}(w) by minimizing (8). Instead, following [13], we define the stochastic approximation h~i‚Äã(Œ∏i,w,ùíüi)subscript~‚ÑéùëñsubscriptùúÉùëñùë§subscriptùíüùëñ\tilde{h}_{i}(\theta_{i},w,\mathcal{D}_{i}) as in Step 14, and minimize this function with respect to Œ∏isubscriptùúÉùëñ\theta_{i} to obtain an approximate solution Œ∏~i‚Äã(w)subscript~ùúÉùëñùë§\tilde{\theta}_{i}(w) where the gradient‚Äôs norm is less than some threshold ŒΩ‚â•0ùúà0\nu\geq 0. Therefore, we approximate (7) with the following estimator:

    ‚àáF~i(c)‚Äã(w,ùíüi)=Œª‚Äã(w‚àíŒ∏~i‚Äã(w)).‚àásubscriptsuperscript~ùêπùëêùëñùë§subscriptùíüùëñùúÜùë§subscript~ùúÉùëñùë§\displaystyle\nabla\tilde{F}^{(c)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})=\lambda\left(w-\tilde{\theta}_{i}(w)\right). (10)

    Let us denote the expectation of h~i(.)\tilde{h}_{i}(.) as hi(.)h_{i}(.). Then, for Œª>LùúÜùêø\lambda>L, the expected function is (Œª+L)ùúÜùêø(\lambda{+}L)-smooth and (Œª‚àíL)ùúÜùêø(\lambda{-}L)-strongly convex due to the properties of Moreau Envelopes [13]. Then according to the property of [7, 13], for some ŒΩ‚â§1ùúà1\nu\leq 1 (e.g., 10‚àí5superscript10510^{{-}5}), we can find Œ∏~i‚Äã(w)subscript~ùúÉùëñùë§\tilde{\theta}_{i}(w) in ùí™‚Äã(Œª+LŒª‚àíL‚Äãlog‚Å°(1ŒΩ))ùí™ùúÜùêøùúÜùêø1ùúà\mathcal{O}(\frac{\lambda{+}L}{\lambda{-}L}\log(\frac{1}{\nu})) iterations.

    We will also discuss the properties of (10) in Subsection 4.3.

Next, we present the convergence result of our method for the three formulations.

4 Convergence Results

In this section, we introduce the technical theorems and lemmas to show the convergence of our method for the three described scenarios. First, we introduce the common assumptions we will use in our analysis for all the three choices of Algorithm 2. As mentioned earlier, we require some additional assumptions to show the convergence of MAML, which we will introduce in Subsection 4.2. After stating the assumptions, we will present the convergence results.

Recall that the server updates its model at round tùë°t using the updates sent by client it‚àà[n]subscriptùëñùë°delimited-[]ùëõi_{t}\in[n]. We denote Œ©‚Äã(t)Œ©ùë°\Omega(t) as the timestep of the round at which client itsubscriptùëñùë°i_{t} has received the server‚Äôs parameters before applying its QùëÑQ local updates. In other words, (Œ©‚Äã(t),t)Œ©ùë°ùë°(\Omega(t),t) denote the download and upload rounds for client itsubscriptùëñùë°i_{t}. Now, we introduce the assumption of maximum delay.

Assumption 1 (Bounded Staleness).

For all server steps t‚â•0ùë°0t\geq 0, the staleness or effective delay between the model version at the download step Œ©‚Äã(t)Œ©ùë°\Omega(t) and upload step tùë°t is bounded by some constant œÑùúè\tau, i.e.,

supt‚â•0|t‚àíŒ©‚Äã(t)|‚â§œÑ,subscriptsupremumùë°0ùë°Œ©ùë°ùúè\displaystyle\sup_{t\geq 0}\left|t-\Omega(t)\right|\leq\tau, (11)

and the server receives updates uniformly, i.e., it‚àºUniform‚Äã([n])similar-tosubscriptùëñùë°Uniformdelimited-[]ùëõi_{t}\sim\mathrm{Uniform}([n]).

The above assumption is standard in the analysis of asynchronous methods, specifically in heterogeneous settings [51, 70, 3, 37, 61, 2]. Assumption 1 guarantees that all clients remain active over the course of training. However, they have transient delays and perform updates with staleness.

Next, we present our only assumption on the function class, i.e., smooth non-convex.

Assumption 2 (Smoothness).

For all clients i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n], function fi:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} is bounded below, differentiable, and LùêøL-smooth, i.e., for all w,u‚àà‚Ñùdùë§ùë¢superscript‚Ñùùëëw,u\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‚à•‚àáfi‚Äã(w)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(u)‚à•‚â§L‚Äã‚à•w‚àíu‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë¢ùêødelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë§ùë¢\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)-\nabla f_{i}(u)\right\rVert\leq L\lVert w-u\rVert (12)
fi‚ãÜ‚âîminw‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°fi‚Äã(w)>‚àí‚àû.‚âîsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëñ‚ãÜsubscriptùë§superscript‚Ñùùëësubscriptùëìùëñùë§\displaystyle f_{i}^{\star}\coloneqq\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f_{i}(w)>-\infty. (13)

The smoothness assumption is conventional in the analysis of non-convex functions. We also assume boundedness from below, which is reasonable since the ultimate goal is to minimize the functions. We also denote f‚ãÜ=mini‚àà[n]‚Å°fi‚ãÜsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜsubscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëñ‚ãÜf^{\star}=\min_{i\in[n]}f_{i}^{\star}, where according to this definition, we can immediately see that f‚ãÜ‚â§minw‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°F(b)‚Äã(w)superscriptùëì‚ãÜsubscriptùë§superscript‚Ñùùëësuperscriptùêπùëèùë§f^{\star}\leq\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F^{(b)}(w) and f‚ãÜ‚â§minw‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°F(c)‚Äã(w)superscriptùëì‚ãÜsubscriptùë§superscript‚Ñùùëësuperscriptùêπùëêùë§f^{\star}\leq\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F^{(c)}(w).

Now, we present our assumptions on bounded stochasticity and heterogeneity.

Assumption 3 (Bounded Variance).

For all clients i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n], the variance of a stochastic gradient ‚àá‚Ñìi‚Äã(w,Œæi)‚àásubscript‚Ñìùëñùë§subscriptùúâùëñ\nabla\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i}) on a single data point Œæi‚ààùíÆisubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùíÆùëñ\xi_{i}\in\mathcal{S}_{i} is bounded, i.e., for all w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

ùîºŒæi‚àºpi‚Äã‚à•‚àá‚Ñìi‚Äã(w,Œæi)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(w)‚à•2‚â§œÉg2.subscriptùîºsimilar-tosubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscript‚Ñìùëñùë§subscriptùúâùëñ‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§2superscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}\sim p_{i}}\left\lVert\nabla\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i})-\nabla f_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\sigma_{g}^{2}. (14)

Assumption 3 is standard in the analysis of SGD-based methods and has been used in many relevant works [62, 51, 35, 67, 36, 37, 64]. Since we perform updates using data batches, we also need to show the stochastic variance for the sampled batches. Recall that for simplicity; we assumed that all batch sizes are larger than b‚â•1ùëè1b\geq 1, thus, we have:

ùîºpi‚Äã‚à•‚àáf~i‚Äã(w,ùíüi)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(w)‚à•2‚â§œÉg2|ùíüi|‚â§œÉa2‚âîœÉg2bsubscriptùîºsubscriptùëùùëñsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscript~ùëìùëñùë§subscriptùíüùëñ‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§2superscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2subscriptùíüùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëé2‚âîsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2ùëè\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left\lVert\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})-\nabla f_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{|\mathcal{D}_{i}|}\leq\sigma_{a}^{2}\coloneqq\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b} (15)

Next, we present the bounded heterogeneity assumption.

Assumption 4 (Bounded Population Diversity).

For all w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the gradients of local functions fi‚Äã(w)subscriptùëìùëñùë§f_{i}(w) and the global function f‚Äã(w)ùëìùë§f(w) satisfy the following property:

1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚à•‚àáfi‚Äã(w)‚àí‚àáf‚Äã(w)‚à•2‚â§Œ≥g2.1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§‚àáùëìùë§2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)-\nabla f(w)\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{g}^{2}. (16)

The above assumption measures the population diversity (heterogeneity) between the gradients. In heterogeneous settings, this bound indicates the similarity between different distributions. Fallah et¬†al. [17] show connections between heterogeneity and the Wasserstein distance between the distributions under certain assumptions.

The above assumptions are sufficient to prove the convergence of our method (Algorithms 1 & 2) under Option A and Option C. Therefore, we present the convergence analyses starting from our results on FedAsync.

4.1 Asynchronous Federated Learning (Option A)

We now demonstrate the convergence rate of our method for the cost function in (1).

Theorem 1 (FedAsync).

Let Assumptions 1-4 hold, Œ≤=1ùõΩ1\beta=1, and Œ∑=1Q‚ÄãL‚ÄãTùúÇ1ùëÑùêøùëá\eta=\frac{1}{Q\sqrt{LT}}. Then, the following property holds for the joint iterates of Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option A on Problem (1): for any timestep T‚â•160‚ÄãL‚Äã(Q+7)‚Äã(œÑ+1)3ùëá160ùêøùëÑ7superscriptùúè13T\geq 160L(Q{+}7)(\tau{+}1)^{3} at the server

1T‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1ùîº‚Äã‚à•‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•21ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\,\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla f\left(w^{t}\right)\right\rVert^{2} ‚â§4‚ÄãL‚Äã(f‚Äã(w0)‚àíf‚ãÜ)T+8‚ÄãL‚Äã(œÉg2b+Œ≥g2)Tabsent4ùêøùëìsuperscriptùë§0superscriptùëì‚ãÜùëá8ùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2ùëèsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2ùëá\displaystyle\leq\frac{4\sqrt{L}\left(f(w^{0})-f^{\star}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}+\frac{8\sqrt{L}\left(\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}+\gamma_{g}^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}
+80‚ÄãL‚Äã(1+Q)‚Äã(œÑ2+1)‚Äã(œÉg2b+Œ≥g2)T.80ùêø1ùëÑsuperscriptùúè21superscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2ùëèsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2ùëá\displaystyle+\frac{80L(1{+}Q)(\tau^{2}{+}1)\left(\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}+\gamma_{g}^{2}\right)}{T}.

The proof of Theorem 1 is provided in Appendix A. This theorem suggests a convergence rate of ùí™‚Äã(1T)+ùí™‚Äã(Q‚ÄãœÑ2T)ùí™1ùëáùí™ùëÑsuperscriptùúè2ùëá\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{Q\tau^{2}}{T}\right) for asynchronous federated learning FedAsync. Our analysis removes the unnecessary boundedness assumption on the gradient norm.

Remark 1.

Selecting Œ≤=1ùõΩ1\beta=1 in Theorem 1, results in a sub-optimal first-order stationary rate for smooth non-convex cost functions. However, this is an arbitrary choice for the value of Œ≤ùõΩ\beta and can be relaxed to any Œ≤=ùí™‚Äã(1)ùõΩùí™1\beta=\mathcal{O}(1) similar to [51].

Next, we present the convergence of PersA-FL-MAML along with some technical lemmas borrowed from [17].

4.2 Personalized Asynchronous Federated Learning: Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning Setup (Option B)

As we discussed in Section 3, we require the second-order derivatives of the local functions to compute the gradients of the personalized costs in (4). Accordingly, we consider similar assumptions for the second-order derivatives as Assumptions 2-4.

Assumption 5 (Second-Order Properties).

For all clients i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n], the following properties hold for the Hessian of each fi:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, the variance of a stochastic Hessian ‚àá2‚Ñìi‚Äã(w,Œæi)superscript‚àá2subscript‚Ñìùëñùë§subscriptùúâùëñ\nabla^{2}\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i}) on a single data point Œæi‚ààùíÆisubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùíÆùëñ\xi_{i}\in\mathcal{S}_{i}, and the global Hessian ‚àá2f‚Äã(w)superscript‚àá2ùëìùë§\nabla^{2}f(w): for all w,u‚àà‚Ñùdùë§ùë¢superscript‚Ñùùëëw,u\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‚à•‚àá2fi‚Äã(w)‚àí‚àá2fi‚Äã(u)‚à•‚â§œÅ‚Äã‚à•w‚àíu‚à•,delimited-‚à•‚à•superscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñùë§superscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñùë¢ùúådelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë§ùë¢\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)-\nabla^{2}f_{i}(u)\right\rVert\leq\rho\lVert w-u\rVert, (17)
ùîºŒæi‚àºpisubscriptùîºsimilar-tosubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}\sim p_{i}} ‚à•‚àá2‚Ñìi‚Äã(w,Œæi)‚àí‚àá2fi‚Äã(w)‚à•2‚â§œÉh2,superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscript‚àá2subscript‚Ñìùëñùë§subscriptùúâùëñsuperscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñùë§2superscriptsubscriptùúé‚Ñé2\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla^{2}\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i})-\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\sigma_{h}^{2}, (18)
1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõ\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} ‚à•‚àá2fi‚Äã(w)‚àí‚àá2f‚Äã(w)‚à•2‚â§Œ≥h2.superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñùë§superscript‚àá2ùëìùë§2superscriptsubscriptùõæ‚Ñé2\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)-\nabla^{2}f(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{h}^{2}. (19)

Assumption 5 is conventional in the analysis of methods with access to second-order information [16, 17, 58, 64]. Finally, we adopt another assumption from [22, 17, 19] on the gradient norm to simplify the analysis for the MAML cost.

Assumption 6 (Bounded-Gradient).

There exists a constant Gùê∫G such that for all clients i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n], and any parameter w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‚à•‚àáfi‚Äã(w)‚à•‚â§G.delimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§ùê∫\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)\right\rVert\leq G. (20)

To the best of our knowledge, seminal works on MAML loss mainly consider this assumption to simplify the properties of the personalized function. Note that we consider Assumptions 5-6 only in the analysis of PersA-FL (Algorithms 1 & 2) under Option B. Under Assumptions 2 and 6, the properties in (19) and (16) can be simply derived with Œ≥h=2‚ÄãLsubscriptùõæ‚Ñé2ùêø\gamma_{h}=2L and Œ≥g=2‚ÄãGsubscriptùõæùëî2ùê∫\gamma_{g}=2G [17].

Before stating the convergence of PersA-FL-MAML, let us state some technical lemmas on the personalized MAML cost function.

Lemma 1 ([17], Lemma 4.2 - Smoothness: MAML).

Let Assumptions 2 and 6 hold. Then, Fi(b)subscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñF^{(b)}_{i} in (4) is LbsubscriptùêøùëèL_{b}-smooth, i.e., for all clients i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n], and any parameters w,u‚àà‚Ñùdùë§ùë¢superscript‚Ñùùëëw,u\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‚à•‚àáFi(b)‚Äã(w)‚àí‚àáFi(b)‚Äã(u)‚à•‚â§Lb‚Äã‚à•w‚àíu‚à•,delimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë§‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë¢subscriptùêøùëèdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë§ùë¢\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)-\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(u)\right\rVert\leq L_{b}\lVert w-u\rVert, (21)

where Lb‚âîL‚Äã(1+Œ±‚ÄãL)2+Œ±‚ÄãœÅ‚ÄãG‚âîsubscriptùêøùëèùêøsuperscript1ùõºùêø2ùõºùúåùê∫L_{b}\coloneqq L(1{+}\alpha L)^{2}+\alpha\rho G.

Lemma 1 indicates that the personalized cost in (4) is also smooth. The smoothness parameter LbsubscriptùêøùëèL_{b} depends on the personalization hyperparameter Œ±ùõº\alpha. Increasing the value of Œ±ùõº\alpha results in higher smoothness constant LbsubscriptùêøùëèL_{b}. The smoothness property of MAML cost under multi-step personalization (instead of one) is shown in [64][Lemma 3].

Lemma 2 ([17], Lemma 4.3 - Bounded Variance: MAML).

Let Assumptions 2, 3, 5, and 6 hold, and data batches ùíü,ùíü‚Ä≤,ùíü‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùíüsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤superscriptùíü‚Ä≤‚Ä≤\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime} be randomly sampled according to data distribution pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}. Then, the following properties hold for the stochastic personalized gradient ‚àáF~i(b)‚Äã(w,ùíü‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,ùíü‚Ä≤,ùíü)‚àásubscriptsuperscript~ùêπùëèùëñùë§superscriptùíü‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùíü‚Ä≤ùíü\nabla\tilde{F}^{(b)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}):

‚à•ùîºpi‚Äã[‚àáF~i(b)‚Äã(w,ùíü‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,ùíü‚Ä≤,ùíü)‚àí‚àáFi(b)‚Äã(w)]‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùîºsubscriptùëùùëñdelimited-[]‚àásubscriptsuperscript~ùêπùëèùëñùë§superscriptùíü‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùíü‚Ä≤ùíü‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë§\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\nabla\tilde{F}^{(b)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D})-\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)\right]\right\rVert ‚â§Œºb‚âîŒ±‚ÄãL‚Äã(1+Œ±‚ÄãL)‚ÄãœÉgb,absentsubscriptùúáùëè‚âîùõºùêø1ùõºùêøsubscriptùúéùëîùëè\displaystyle\leq\mu_{b}\coloneqq\frac{\alpha L(1{+}\alpha L)\sigma_{g}}{\sqrt{b}}, (22)
ùîºpi‚Äã‚à•‚àáF~i(b)‚Äã(w,ùíü‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,ùíü‚Ä≤,ùíü)‚àí‚àáFi(b)‚Äã(w)‚à•2subscriptùîºsubscriptùëùùëñsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptsuperscript~ùêπùëèùëñùë§superscriptùíü‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùíü‚Ä≤ùíü‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë§2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left\lVert\nabla\tilde{F}^{(b)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D})-\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2} ‚â§œÉb2,absentsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëè2\displaystyle\leq\sigma_{b}^{2}, (23)

for all w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where œÉb2‚âî3‚Äã(1+Œ±‚ÄãL)2‚ÄãœÉg2‚Äã[1b+Œ±2‚ÄãL2b]+3‚ÄãŒ±2‚ÄãG2‚ÄãœÉh2b+3‚ÄãŒ±2‚ÄãœÉg2‚ÄãœÉh2b‚Äã[1b+Œ±2‚ÄãL2b]‚âîsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëè23superscript1ùõºùêø2superscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2delimited-[]1ùëèsuperscriptùõº2superscriptùêø2ùëè3superscriptùõº2superscriptùê∫2superscriptsubscriptùúé‚Ñé2ùëè3superscriptùõº2superscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2superscriptsubscriptùúé‚Ñé2ùëèdelimited-[]1ùëèsuperscriptùõº2superscriptùêø2ùëè\sigma_{b}^{2}\coloneqq 3(1{+}\alpha L)^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}\left[\frac{1}{b}{+}\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}}{b}\right]+3\alpha^{2}G^{2}\frac{\sigma_{h}^{2}}{b}+\frac{3\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}\sigma_{h}^{2}}{b}\left[\frac{1}{b}{+}\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}}{b}\right].

Lemma 2 highlights two important results. First, the stochastic gradient in (9) is a biased estimation of the full gradient 5. The biasness is controlled by two factors, personalization stepsize Œ±ùõº\alpha, and batch size bùëèb.444It should be noted that the batch size in the upper bound of (22) refers to the size of |ùíü‚Ä≤|superscriptùíü‚Ä≤|\mathcal{D}^{\prime}|. Recall that we use this batch to approximate the inner gradient in 10. Therefore, we obtain an unbiased estimation under no personalization, i.e., Œ±=0ùõº0\alpha=0. However, as we select a larger Œ±ùõº\alpha, we require more samples to reduce the error imposed by biased gradient estimations. Second, similar to Assumption 3 on the cost; we have a tight variance based on Œ±ùõº\alpha and bùëèb.

Lemma 3 ([17], Lemma 4.4 - Bounded Population Diversity: MAML).

For all w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the gradients of local personalized functions Fi(b)‚Äã(w)subscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë§F^{(b)}_{i}(w) and the global function F(b)‚Äã(w)superscriptùêπùëèùë§F^{(b)}(w) satisfy the following property:

1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚à•‚àáFi(b)‚Äã(w)‚àí‚àáF(b)‚Äã(w)‚à•2‚â§Œ≥b2‚âî12‚Äã(1+Œ±‚ÄãL)2‚Äã[1+Œ±2‚ÄãL2]‚ÄãŒ≥g2+12‚ÄãŒ±2‚ÄãG2‚ÄãŒ≥h2.1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë§‚àásuperscriptùêπùëèùë§2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëè2‚âî12superscript1ùõºùêø2delimited-[]1superscriptùõº2superscriptùêø2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëî212superscriptùõº2superscriptùê∫2superscriptsubscriptùõæ‚Ñé2\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)-\nabla F^{(b)}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{b}^{2}\coloneqq 12(1+\alpha L)^{2}\left[1+\alpha^{2}L^{2}\right]\gamma_{g}^{2}+12\alpha^{2}G^{2}\gamma_{h}^{2}. (24)

The above lemma determines the heterogeneity of the personalized gradients ‚àáFi(b)‚Äã(w)‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùêπùëñùëèùë§\nabla F_{i}^{(b)}(w) based on the heterogeneity of gradient and Hessian. One can see the connection of this bound with ùí™‚Äã(Œ≥g2)+Œ±2‚Äãùí™‚Äã(Œ≥h2)ùí™superscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2superscriptùõº2ùí™superscriptsubscriptùõæ‚Ñé2\mathcal{O}(\gamma_{g}^{2})+\alpha^{2}\mathcal{O}(\gamma_{h}^{2}), whereby setting Œ±=0ùõº0\alpha=0, we recover the same heterogeneity in terms of ùí™‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùí™‚ãÖ\mathcal{O}(\cdot) notion.

Lemma 4 (Bounded-Gradient: MAML).

For all clients i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n], and any parameter w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‚à•‚àáFi(b)‚Äã(w)‚à•‚â§Gb‚âî(1+Œ±‚ÄãL)‚ÄãG.delimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëèùëñùë§subscriptùê∫ùëè‚âî1ùõºùêøùê∫\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)\right\rVert\leq G_{b}\coloneqq(1{+}\alpha L)G. (25)

This lemma indicates that the bound on the norm of personalized gradients potentially increases under a larger personalization budget Œ±ùõº\alpha.

Building upon the results in Lemmas 2-(25), we are now ready to present the convergence result for PersA-FL-MAML.

Theorem 2 (PersA-FL-MAML).

Let Assumptions 1-6 hold, Œ±‚â•0ùõº0\alpha\geq 0, Œ≤=1ùõΩ1\beta=1, and Œ∑=1Q‚ÄãLb‚ÄãTùúÇ1ùëÑsubscriptùêøùëèùëá\eta=\frac{1}{Q\sqrt{L_{b}T}}. Then, the following property holds for the joint iterates of Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option B on Problem (4): for any timestep T‚â•64‚ÄãLbùëá64subscriptùêøùëèT\geq 64L_{b} at the server

1T‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1ùîº‚Äã‚à•‚àáF(b)‚Äã(wt)‚à•21ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásuperscriptùêπùëèsuperscriptùë§ùë°2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum\limits_{t=0}^{T{-}1}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla F^{(b)}(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2} ‚â§4‚ÄãLb‚Äã(F(b)‚Äã(w0)‚àíf‚ãÜ)T+8‚ÄãLb‚Äã(œÉb2+Œ≥b2)Tabsent4subscriptùêøùëèsuperscriptùêπùëèsuperscriptùë§0superscriptùëì‚ãÜùëá8subscriptùêøùëèsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëè2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëè2ùëá\displaystyle\leq\frac{4\sqrt{L_{b}}\left(F^{(b)}(w^{0})-f^{\star}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}+\frac{8\sqrt{L_{b}}\left(\sigma_{b}^{2}+\gamma_{b}^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}
+20‚ÄãQ‚ÄãLb‚Äã(Gb2+œÉb2)‚Äã(œÑ2+1)T+4‚ÄãQ‚ÄãŒ±2‚ÄãL2‚Äã(1+Œ±‚ÄãL)2‚ÄãœÉg2b.20ùëÑsubscriptùêøùëèsuperscriptsubscriptùê∫ùëè2superscriptsubscriptùúéùëè2superscriptùúè21ùëá4ùëÑsuperscriptùõº2superscriptùêø2superscript1ùõºùêø2superscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2ùëè\displaystyle+\frac{20\,QL_{b}\left(G_{b}^{2}{+}\sigma_{b}^{2}\right)\left(\tau^{2}{+}1\right)}{T}+\frac{4\,Q\alpha^{2}L^{2}(1{+}\alpha L)^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}.

The proof of this theorem can be found in Appendix B. Theorem 2 shows a convergence rate of ùí™‚Äã(1T)+ùí™‚Äã(œÑ2T)+ùí™‚Äã(Œ±2‚ÄãœÉg2b)ùí™1ùëáùí™superscriptùúè2ùëáùí™superscriptùõº2superscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2ùëè\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\tau^{2}}{T}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}\right) for PersA-FL algorithm under MAML setup. Now, let us compare this rate with the convergence rate of FedAsync and Per-FedAvg, as in Table 1. The last term in the above rate, i.e., ùí™‚Äã(Œ±2‚ÄãœÉg2b)ùí™superscriptùõº2superscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2ùëè\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}\right) accounts for personalization with biased gradient estimation. Moreover, compared to Per-FedAvg, the second term of this rate is different, which accounts for the maximum delay in asynchronous updates.

To achieve the optimal complexity bound for the result in Theorem 2, we show how to choose the parameters T,bùëáùëèT,b based on the desired accuracy ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon in the following corollary.

Corollary 1 (PersA-FL-MAML ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon-convergence).

Suppose the conditions in Theorem 2 are satisfied. Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option B finds an ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon first-order stationary solution for F(b)superscriptùêπùëèF^{(b)} in (4) by setting T=ùí™‚Äã(Œµ‚àí2)ùëáùí™superscriptùúÄ2T=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{-2}) and b=ùí™‚Äã(Œµ‚àí1)ùëèùí™superscriptùúÄ1b=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{-1}) given a fixed personalization budget Œ±‚â•0ùõº0\alpha\geq 0.

The result in Corollary 1 highlights the required communication and sample complexity for ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon first-order stationary convergence. Moreover, note that the last expression in Theorem 2 can also be controlled through a combined stepsize Œ±ùõº\alpha and batch size bùëèb. This result is consistent with intuition, i.e., more samples are required to obtain a higher degree of personalization.

Next, we will present the analysis of PersA-FL-ME.

4.3 Personalized Asynchronous Federated Learning: Moreau Envelope Setup (Option C)

In this subsection, we show three technical lemmas on the bounded variance of stochasticity and heterogeneity as well as smoothness for ME formulation (6) and then present the convergence rate of PersA-FL for this personalization framework. The proof of all results in this subsection is provided in Appendix C.

First, we present the smoothness property of ME loss.

Lemma 5 (Smoothness: ME).

Let Assumption 2 holds and Œª‚â•Œ∫‚ÄãLùúÜùúÖùêø\lambda\geq\kappa L for some Œ∫>1ùúÖ1\kappa>1. Then, Fi(c)subscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñF^{(c)}_{i} in (6) is LcsubscriptùêøùëêL_{c}-smooth, where Lc=ŒªŒ∫‚àí1subscriptùêøùëêùúÜùúÖ1L_{c}=\frac{\lambda}{\kappa{-}1}.

According to Lemma 5, we limit our exploration to Œª>LùúÜùêø\lambda>L which satisfies the smoothness constraint for the ME formulation. In fact, according to Appendix C, one can also see that originally, each Fi(c)‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñ‚ãÖF^{(c)}_{i}(\cdot) is Œª‚ÄãLŒª‚àíLùúÜùêøùúÜùêø\frac{\lambda L}{\lambda{-}L}-smooth which is also smaller than Lc=ŒªŒ∫‚àí1subscriptùêøùëêùúÜùúÖ1L_{c}=\frac{\lambda}{\kappa{-}1}. As we mentioned in Section 2, when Œª‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùúÜ\lambda\to\infty, ME framework converts to FL. The smoothness property in Lemma 5 is tight because, Lc‚ÜíL‚ÜísubscriptùêøùëêùêøL_{c}\to L if Œª‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùúÜ\lambda\to\infty.

Corollary 2 ([13], Proposition 1).

If Œª‚â•2‚ÄãLùúÜ2ùêø\lambda\geq 2L, then Lemma 5 implies that Fi(c)subscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñF^{(c)}_{i} in (6) is ŒªùúÜ\lambda-smooth.

Lemma 6 (Bounded Variance: ME).

Let Assumptions 2 and 3 hold, Œª‚â•Œ∫‚ÄãLùúÜùúÖùêø\lambda\geq\kappa L (for some Œ∫>1ùúÖ1\kappa>1), and the data batch ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} be randomly sampled according to data distribution pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}. Then, the following properties hold for the stochastic personalized gradient ‚àáF~i(c)‚Äã(w,ùíü)‚àásubscriptsuperscript~ùêπùëêùëñùë§ùíü\nabla\tilde{F}^{(c)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}): for all w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‚à•ùîºpi‚Äã[‚àáF~i(c)‚Äã(w,ùíü)‚àí‚àáFi(c)‚Äã(w)]‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùîºsubscriptùëùùëñdelimited-[]‚àásubscriptsuperscript~ùêπùëêùëñùë§ùíü‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñùë§\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\nabla\tilde{F}^{(c)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D})-\nabla F^{(c)}_{i}(w)\right]\right\rVert ‚â§Œºc‚âîŒªŒª‚àíL‚ÄãŒΩ,absentsubscriptùúáùëê‚âîùúÜùúÜùêøùúà\displaystyle\leq\mu_{c}\coloneqq\frac{\lambda}{\lambda{-}L}\nu, (26)
ùîºpi‚Äã‚à•‚àáF~i(c)‚Äã(w,ùíü)‚àí‚àáFi(c)‚Äã(w)‚à•2subscriptùîºsubscriptùëùùëñsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptsuperscript~ùêπùëêùëñùë§ùíü‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñùë§2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left\lVert\nabla\tilde{F}^{(c)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D})-\nabla F^{(c)}_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2} ‚â§œÉc2‚âî2‚ÄãŒª2(Œª‚àíL)2‚Äã[œÉg2b+ŒΩ2].absentsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëê2‚âî2superscriptùúÜ2superscriptùúÜùêø2delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùúéùëî2ùëèsuperscriptùúà2\displaystyle\leq\sigma_{c}^{2}\coloneqq\frac{2\lambda^{2}}{\left(\lambda{-}L\right)^{2}}\left[\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}+\nu^{2}\right]. (27)

This lemma is analogous to Lemma 2 in Subsection 4.2. In Lemma 6, we show an upper bound on the variance and bias of the stochastic gradient compared to the full gradient. Note that when Œª‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùúÜ\lambda\to\infty, we know that Œ∏^i‚Äã(w)‚Üíw‚Üísubscript^ùúÉùëñùë§ùë§\hat{\theta}_{i}(w)\to w. Therefore, by fixing Œ∏~i‚Äã(w)=wsubscript~ùúÉùëñùë§ùë§\tilde{\theta}_{i}(w)=w, it is guaranteed that ŒΩ=0ùúà0\nu=0, thus our gradient estimation becomes unbiased and the variance similar to (15).

Lemma 7 (Bounded Population Diversity: ME).

Let personalization hyperparameter Œª‚â•7‚ÄãLùúÜ7ùêø\lambda\geq 7L. Then, for all w‚àà‚Ñùdùë§superscript‚Ñùùëëw\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the gradients of local personalized functions Fi(c)‚Äã(w)subscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñùë§F^{(c)}_{i}(w) and the global ME function F(c)‚Äã(w)superscriptùêπùëêùë§F^{(c)}(w) satisfy the following property:

1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚à•‚àáFi(c)‚Äã(w)‚àí‚àáF(c)‚Äã(w)‚à•2‚â§Œ≥c2‚âî16‚ÄãŒª2Œª2‚àí48‚ÄãL2‚ÄãŒ≥g2.1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptsuperscriptùêπùëêùëñùë§‚àásuperscriptùêπùëêùë§2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëê2‚âî16superscriptùúÜ2superscriptùúÜ248superscriptùêø2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert\nabla F^{(c)}_{i}(w)-\nabla F^{(c)}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{c}^{2}\coloneqq\frac{16\lambda^{2}}{\lambda^{2}{-}48L^{2}}\gamma_{g}^{2}. (28)

Lemma 7 provides a bound on population diversity of ME as a factor of Œ≥g2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2\gamma_{g}^{2}. Similar to what we explained so far, for Œª‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùúÜ\lambda\to\infty, the heterogeneity bound turns into Œ≥g2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2\gamma_{g}^{2}.

Remark 2.

In the analysis for Theorem 3, we consider bounded population diversity as in Assumption 4, average bounded diversity. [13][Assumption 3] and [68][6.1.1 Assumptions and Preliminaries, (vii)] consider a slightly stronger version of this assumption, namely uniformly ‚Äúbounded heterogeneity‚Äù which is defined as follows:

maxi‚àà[n]‚Äãsupw‚àà‚Ñùd‚à•‚àáfi‚Äã(w)‚àí‚àáf‚Äã(w)‚à•2‚â§Œ≥g2.subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõsubscriptsupremumùë§superscript‚Ñùùëësuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§‚àáùëìùë§2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2\displaystyle\max_{i\in[n]}\sup_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)-\nabla f(w)\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{g}^{2}. (29)

Under the modified assumption in (29), we can improve Œ≥c2‚âî16‚ÄãŒª2Œª2‚àí8‚ÄãL2‚ÄãŒ≥g2‚âîsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëê216superscriptùúÜ2superscriptùúÜ28superscriptùêø2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2\gamma_{c}^{2}\coloneqq\frac{16\lambda^{2}}{\lambda^{2}{-}8L^{2}}\gamma_{g}^{2}.

Now, we present our convergence result of PersA-FL-ME under Assumption 1-4

Theorem 3 (PersA-FL-ME).

Let Assumptions 1-4 hold, Œª‚â•7‚ÄãLùúÜ7ùêø\lambda\geq 7L, Œ≤=1ùõΩ1\beta=1, and Œ∑=1Q‚ÄãLc‚ÄãTùúÇ1ùëÑsubscriptùêøùëêùëá\eta=\frac{1}{Q\sqrt{L_{c}T}}. Then, the following property holds for the joint iterates of Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option C on Problem (6): for any timestep T‚â•288‚ÄãLc‚Äã(Q+7)‚Äã(œÑ+1)2ùëá288subscriptùêøùëêùëÑ7superscriptùúè12T\geq 288L_{c}(Q{+}7)(\tau{+}1)^{2} at the server

1T‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1ùîº‚Äã‚à•‚àáF(c)‚Äã(wt)‚à•21ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásuperscriptùêπùëêsuperscriptùë§ùë°2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum\limits_{t=0}^{T{-}1}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla F^{(c)}(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2} ‚â§4‚ÄãLc‚Äã(F(c)‚Äã(wt)‚àíf‚ãÜ)T+8‚ÄãLc‚Äã(œÉc2+Œ≥c2)Tabsent4subscriptùêøùëêsuperscriptùêπùëêsuperscriptùë§ùë°superscriptùëì‚ãÜùëá8subscriptùêøùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëê2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëê2ùëá\displaystyle\leq\frac{4\sqrt{L_{c}}\left(F^{(c)}(w^{t})-f^{\star}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}+\frac{8\sqrt{L_{c}}\left(\sigma_{c}^{2}+\gamma_{c}^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}
+144‚ÄãLc‚Äã(1+Q)‚Äã(œÑ2+1)‚Äã(œÉc2+Œ≥g2)T+4‚ÄãQ‚ÄãŒª2‚ÄãŒΩ2(Œª‚àíL)2.144subscriptùêøùëê1ùëÑsuperscriptùúè21superscriptsubscriptùúéùëê2superscriptsubscriptùõæùëî2ùëá4ùëÑsuperscriptùúÜ2superscriptùúà2superscriptùúÜùêø2\displaystyle+\frac{144L_{c}(1{+}Q)(\tau^{2}{+}1)\left(\sigma_{c}^{2}+\gamma_{g}^{2}\right)}{T}+\frac{4Q\lambda^{2}\nu^{2}}{(\lambda{-}L)^{2}}.

Theorem 3 proposes a convergence rate of ùí™‚Äã(1T)+ùí™‚Äã(œÑ2T)+ùí™‚Äã(Œª2‚ÄãŒΩ2(Œª‚àíL)2)ùí™1ùëáùí™superscriptùúè2ùëáùí™superscriptùúÜ2superscriptùúà2superscriptùúÜùêø2\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\tau^{2}}{T}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\lambda^{2}\nu^{2}}{(\lambda{-}L)^{2}}\right) for PersA-FL under ME formulation. Again, under the exact same reasoning as Lemma 6, we know that ŒΩ=0ùúà0\nu=0 when Œª‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùúÜ\lambda\to\infty, thus the convergence rate simply reduces to FedAsync with no personalization. Moreover, let us compare the convergence result in Theorem 3 with the rate of pFedMe [13] in Table 1. By comparing the last terms in both rates, ùí™‚Äã(Œª2‚ÄãŒΩ2(Œª‚àíL)2)ùí™superscriptùúÜ2superscriptùúà2superscriptùúÜùêø2\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\frac{\lambda^{2}\nu^{2}}{(\lambda{-}L)^{2}}\Big{)} and ùí™‚Äã(Œª2‚Äã(1b+ŒΩ2)(Œª‚àíL)2)ùí™superscriptùúÜ21ùëèsuperscriptùúà2superscriptùúÜùêø2\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\frac{\lambda^{2}\left(\frac{1}{b}+\nu^{2}\right)}{(\lambda{-}L)^{2}}\Big{)}, one can see that the additional term 1b1ùëè\frac{1}{b} in the convergence rate of pFedMe, implies that even under Œª‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùúÜ\lambda\to\infty (i.e., no personalization), the last term does not vanish unless we select large data batches, i.e., b=ùí™‚Äã(Œµ‚àí1)ùëèùí™superscriptùúÄ1b=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{-1}). Therefore, from the personalization perspective, our analysis provides a tighter bound compared to pFedMe.

In the next corollary, we characterize a choice of T,ŒΩùëáùúàT,\nu in Theorem 3, given a desired accuracy level ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon for our proposed algorithm in Option C.

Corollary 3 (PersA-FL-ME ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon-convergence).

Suppose the conditions in Theorem 3 are satisfied. Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option C finds an ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon first-order stationary solution for F(c)superscriptùêπùëêF^{(c)} in (6) by setting T=ùí™‚Äã(Œµ‚àí2)ùëáùí™superscriptùúÄ2T=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{-2}) and ŒΩ=ùí™‚Äã(Œµ1/2)ùúàùí™superscriptùúÄ12\nu=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{{1}/{2}}) given a fixed personalization budget ŒªùúÜ\lambda.

Corollary 1 determines the communication complexity and precision of the approximate gradient estimator to achieve an ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon first-order stationary convergence. This means that if we choose ŒΩ=ùí™‚Äã(Œµ1/2)ùúàùí™superscriptùúÄ12\nu=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{{1}/{2}}), then the inexact optimization solver should compute the solution up to accuracy O‚Äã(ŒΩ)ùëÇùúàO(\nu) of the surrogate optimization problem in order to achieve an ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon-first order stationary solution. Also, we would like to highlight that this result implies no direct dependence on the batch size (b) for the convergence result of our algorithm with Option C(cf. [13]).

5 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we evaluate the performance of our method in settings with delayed communications. We focus on the aspects of concurrency, speed-up, and accuracy.

Let us first start by explaining our simulation setup for communications with delays. We consider a set of n=30ùëõ30n{=}30 different clients. Each of the clients has a set of random delays at the upload and download stage. The random delays are generated such that the average upload delay is 444 to 666 times higher than the average download delay. Moreover, we assume that the time for communication and aggregation is much larger than the time for local updates, thus we focus on the communication time. First, we show the number of active (not idle) users during the training process under asynchronous communications. The orange curve in Figure 2(a) shows the proportion of active users, which is up to 80%percent8080\% on average over time. We also plot the average proportion of users sampled in the synchronous updates in the same figure with green color. As Figure 2(a) demonstrates, the concurrency level for asynchronous methods is considerably higher than that of their synchronous counterparts.

We create extremely heterogeneous distributed data from MNIST [41] and CIFAR-10 [39] datasets for the clients, meaning that each client holds a different and skewed distribution of images from various classes. To build the heterogeneous data, we assign each client i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n] samples from only cùëêc out of 101010 classes of the data. Over the underlying communication setup and heterogeneous data setting, we compare the speed and accuracy of FedAvg, Per-FedAvg, pFedMe, SCAFFOLD555Scaffold algorithm has two options. Option I makes another pass over the local data to compute the gradient at the server model. Therefore, we consider SCAFFOLD (Option I), which is more stable in practice [34]., FedAsync, PersA-FL-MAML, PersA-FL-ME, where the first four methods are synchronous and the rest are asynchronous. For MNIST and CIFAR-10, we consider convolutional networks [39] followed by fully connected layers with pooling and dropout as well as cross-entropy loss. Details on the experimental setups can be found in AppendixD.

Figure 2 (b) and Figure 2 (c) compares the performance and convergence speed of our methods (PersA-FL-MAML & PersA-FL-ME) with the other five algorithms respectively on heterogeneous MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. We would like to emphasize that in these two figures, each point on each curve represents the accuracy of the corresponding method after local fine-tuning with the same personalization budget as personalized personalized algorithm. In other words, similar to the four personalized methods, Per-FedAvg, pFedMe, PersA-FL-MAML, and PersA-FL-ME, we consider same amount of fine-tuning budget for the three non-personalized methods. FedAvg, SCAFFOLD, and FedAsync. As shown in Figure 2, our methods outperform the other methods within a fixed communication time. Moreover, the ME loss function results in a more stable and efficient performance compared to MAML.

6 Conclusion

This work studied the personalized federated learning problem for the heterogeneous data setting under asynchronous communications with the server. We considered the Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) and Moreau Envelope (ME) formulations to account for personalization. We proposed the PersA-FL algorithm to solve this problem under stale updates. We showed the convergence rate of our method for smooth non-convex functions asynchronous federated learning, and personalized federated learning under the two personalization formulations, i.e., MAML and ME. Particularly, for asynchronous federated learning and personalized federated learning under Moreau Envelope costs, we presented a proof technique that does not require a boundedness assumption on the gradient norm. We finally show numerical results that illustrate the benefits of our proposed method in terms of accuracy and scalability. The studies of generalization and communication efficiency will be left to future research. Moreover, the extensions of our method to the buffered aggregation and decentralized setups remain for future studies.

Appendix A Asynchronous Federated Learning

Proof of Theorem 1.

First, we present a set of useful inequalities we will use in the proof. For any set of mùëöm vectors {wi}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëñ1ùëö\{w_{i}\}_{i{=}1}^{m} such that wi‚àà‚Ñùdsubscriptùë§ùëñsuperscript‚Ñùùëëw_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, and a constant Œ±>0ùõº0\alpha>0, the following properties hold: for all i,j‚àà[m]ùëñùëódelimited-[]ùëöi,j\in[m]:

‚à•wi+wj‚à•2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë§ùëñsubscriptùë§ùëó2\displaystyle\lVert w_{i}+w_{j}\rVert^{2} ‚â§(1+Œ±)‚Äã‚à•wi‚à•2+(1+Œ±‚àí1)‚Äã‚à•wj‚à•2,absent1ùõºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë§ùëñ21superscriptùõº1superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë§ùëó2\displaystyle\leq(1{+}\alpha)\lVert w_{i}\rVert^{2}+(1{+}\alpha^{-1})\lVert w_{j}\rVert^{2}, (30a)
‚à•wi+wj‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë§ùëñsubscriptùë§ùëó\displaystyle\lVert w_{i}+w_{j}\rVert ‚â§‚à•wi‚à•+‚à•wj‚à•,absentdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë§ùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë§ùëó\displaystyle\leq\lVert w_{i}\rVert+\lVert w_{j}\rVert, (30b)
2‚Äã‚ü®wi,wj‚ü©2subscriptùë§ùëñsubscriptùë§ùëó\displaystyle 2\langle w_{i},w_{j}\rangle ‚â§Œ±‚Äã‚à•wi‚à•2+Œ±‚àí1‚Äã‚à•wj‚à•2,absentùõºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë§ùëñ2superscriptùõº1superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë§ùëó2\displaystyle\leq\alpha\lVert w_{i}\rVert^{2}+\alpha^{-1}\lVert w_{j}\rVert^{2}, (30c)
‚à•‚àëi=1mwi‚à•2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscriptùë§ùëñ2\displaystyle\left\lVert\sum\limits_{i=1}^{m}w_{i}\right\rVert^{2} ‚â§m‚Äã(‚àëi=1m‚à•wi‚à•2).absentùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë§ùëñ2\displaystyle\leq m\left(\sum\limits_{i=1}^{m}\lVert w_{i}\rVert^{2}\right). (30d)

Now, let us rewrite the update rule of the joint iterates in Algorithms 1 & 2 Option A at time tùë°t as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Client update:

    wi,0tsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñ0ùë°\displaystyle w_{i,0}^{t} =wt,absentsuperscriptùë§ùë°\displaystyle=w^{t}, (31)
    wi,q+1tsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëû1ùë°\displaystyle w_{i,q{+}1}^{t} =wi,qt‚àíŒ∑‚Äã‚àáf~i‚Äã(wi,qt,ùíüi,qt),absentsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëûùë°ùúÇ‚àásubscript~ùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëûùë°superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùëûùë°\displaystyle=w_{i,q}^{t}-\eta\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}(w_{i,q}^{t},\mathcal{D}_{i,q}^{t}), (32)
  • ‚Ä¢

    Server update:

    wt+1=wt‚àíŒ≤‚ÄãŒîit=wt‚àíŒ∑‚ÄãŒ≤‚Äã‚àëq=0Q‚àí1‚àáf~it‚Äã(wit,qŒ©‚Äã(t),ùíüi,qŒ©‚Äã(t)).superscriptùë§ùë°1superscriptùë§ùë°ùõΩsubscriptŒîsubscriptùëñùë°superscriptùë§ùë°ùúÇùõΩsuperscriptsubscriptùëû0ùëÑ1‚àásubscript~ùëìsubscriptùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùë§subscriptùëñùë°ùëûŒ©ùë°superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùëûŒ©ùë°\displaystyle w^{t{+}1}=w^{t}-\beta\Delta_{i_{t}}=w^{t}-\eta\beta\sum\limits_{q=0}^{Q{-}1}\nabla\tilde{f}_{i_{t}}\left(w_{i_{t},q}^{\Omega(t)},\mathcal{D}_{i,q}^{\Omega(t)}\right). (33)

For simplicity, we denote ‚àá~‚Äãfi‚Äã(w)=‚àáf~i‚Äã(w,ùíüi)~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë§‚àásubscript~ùëìùëñùë§subscriptùíüùëñ\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(w\right)=\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}\left(w,\mathcal{D}_{i}\right). Therefore, at round tùë°t, the server updates its parameter by receiving ŒîitsubscriptŒîsubscriptùëñùë°\Delta_{i_{t}} from some client it‚àà[n]subscriptùëñùë°delimited-[]ùëõi_{t}\in[n], as follows:

wt+1=wt‚àíŒ∑‚ÄãŒ≤‚Äã‚àëq=0Q‚àí1‚àá~‚Äãfit‚Äã(wit,qŒ©‚Äã(t)).superscriptùë§ùë°1superscriptùë§ùë°ùúÇùõΩsuperscriptsubscriptùëû0ùëÑ1~‚àásubscriptùëìsubscriptùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùë§subscriptùëñùë°ùëûŒ©ùë°\displaystyle w^{t{+}1}=w^{t}-\eta\beta\sum\limits_{q=0}^{Q{-}1}\tilde{\nabla}f_{i_{t}}\left(w_{i_{t},q}^{\Omega(t)}\right). (34)

Moreover, Due to Assumption 2, we can infer that fùëìf is LùêøL-smooth, thus

f‚Äã(wt+1)‚Äã‚â§(‚Äã12‚Äã)‚Äãf‚Äã(wt)‚àíŒ∑‚ÄãŒ≤‚Äã‚ü®‚àáf‚Äã(wt),‚àëq=0Q‚àí1‚àá~‚Äãfit‚Äã(wit,qŒ©‚Äã(t))‚ü©‚èü=‚Å£:Sa1+L‚ÄãŒ∑2‚ÄãŒ≤22‚Äã‚à•‚àëq=0Q‚àí1‚àá~‚Äãfit‚Äã(wit,qŒ©‚Äã(t))‚à•2‚èü=‚Å£:Sa2ùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°1italic-(12italic-)ùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°ùúÇùõΩsubscript‚èü‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëû0ùëÑ1~‚àásubscriptùëìsubscriptùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùë§subscriptùëñùë°ùëûŒ©ùë°:absentsubscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé1ùêøsuperscriptùúÇ2superscriptùõΩ22subscript‚èüsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëû0ùëÑ1~‚àásubscriptùëìsubscriptùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùë§subscriptùëñùë°ùëûŒ©ùë°2:absentsubscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé2\displaystyle f\left(w^{t{+}1}\right)\overset{\eqref{eq:smoothness}}{\leq}f(w^{t})-\eta\beta\underbrace{\left\langle\nabla f(w^{t}),\sum\limits_{q=0}^{Q{-}1}\tilde{\nabla}f_{i_{t}}\left(w_{i_{t},q}^{\Omega(t)}\right)\right\rangle}_{=:S_{a_{1}}}+\frac{L\eta^{2}\beta^{2}}{2}\underbrace{\left\lVert\sum\limits_{q=0}^{Q{-}1}\tilde{\nabla}f_{i_{t}}\left(w_{i_{t},q}^{\Omega(t)}\right)\right\rVert^{2}}_{=:S_{a_{2}}} (35)

First, we provide a lower bound on term Sa1subscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé1S_{a_{1}} in (35). Prior to show the bound, let us denote g~it=‚àëq=0Q‚àí1‚àá~‚Äãfi‚Äã(wi,qŒ©‚Äã(t))superscriptsubscript~ùëîùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùëû0ùëÑ1~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëûŒ©ùë°\tilde{g}_{i}^{t}=\sum\limits_{q{=}0}^{Q{-}1}\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(w_{i,q}^{\Omega(t)}\right), g~t=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1ng~itsuperscript~ùëîùë°1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscript~ùëîùëñùë°\tilde{g}^{t}=\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i{=}1}^{n}\tilde{g}_{i}^{t}, git=‚àëq=0Q‚àí1‚àáfi‚Äã(wi,qŒ©‚Äã(t))superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùëû0ùëÑ1‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëûŒ©ùë°g_{i}^{t}=\sum\limits_{q{=}0}^{Q{-}1}\nabla f_{i}\left(w_{i,q}^{\Omega(t)}\right), and gt=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1ngitsuperscriptùëîùë°1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùë°g^{t}=\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i{=}1}^{n}g_{i}^{t}. Therefore,

ùîº‚Äã[Sa1]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé1\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[S_{a_{1}}\right] =ùîº‚Äã[ùîºit‚Äã‚ü®‚àáf‚Äã(wt),g~itt‚ü©]absentùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùîºsubscriptùëñùë°‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°superscriptsubscript~ùëîsubscriptùëñùë°ùë°\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}_{i_{t}}\left\langle\nabla f(w^{t}),\tilde{g}_{i_{t}}^{t}\right\rangle\right] (36)
=ùîº‚Äã[‚ü®‚àáf‚Äã(wt),1n‚Äã‚àëi=1ng~it‚ü©]absentùîºdelimited-[]‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscript~ùëîùëñùë°\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\nabla f(w^{t}),\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\tilde{g}_{i}^{t}\right\rangle\right] (37)
=ùîº‚Äã‚ü®‚àáf‚Äã(wt),1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nùîºpi‚Äã[g~it]‚ü©=ùîº‚Äã‚ü®‚àáf‚Äã(wt),1n‚Äã‚àëi=1ngit‚ü©absentùîº‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùîºsubscriptùëùùëñdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript~ùëîùëñùë°ùîº‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùë°\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left\langle\nabla f(w^{t}),\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\tilde{g}_{i}^{t}\right]\right\rangle=\mathbb{E}\left\langle\nabla f(w^{t}),\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}g_{i}^{t}\right\rangle (38)
=Q‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚à•‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•2+ùîº‚Äã‚ü®‚àáf‚Äã(wt),gt‚àíQ‚Äã‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚ü©absentùëÑùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°2ùîº‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°superscriptùëîùë°ùëÑ‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°\displaystyle=Q\,\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla f(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2}+\mathbb{E}\left\langle\nabla f(w^{t}),g^{t}-Q\nabla f(w^{t})\right\rangle (39)
‚â•Q‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚à•‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•2‚àí12‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚à•‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•2‚àí12‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚à•gt‚àíQ‚Äã‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•2absentùëÑùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°212ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°212ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùëîùë°ùëÑ‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°2\displaystyle{\geq}Q\,\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla f(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla f(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert g^{t}-Q\nabla f(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2} (40)
=2‚ÄãQ‚àí12‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚à•‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•2‚àí12‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚à•gt‚àíQ‚Äã‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•2.absent2ùëÑ12ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°212ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùëîùë°ùëÑ‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°2\displaystyle=\frac{2Q{-}1}{2}\,\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla f(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert g^{t}-Q\nabla f(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2}. (41)

Moreover, the following holds for Sa2subscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé2S_{a_{2}} in (35):

ùîºit‚Äã[Sa2]=ùîºit‚Äã‚à•‚àëq=0Q‚àí1‚àá~‚Äãfit‚Äã(wit,qŒ©‚Äã(t))‚à•2=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚à•g~it‚à•2.subscriptùîºsubscriptùëñùë°delimited-[]subscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé2subscriptùîºsubscriptùëñùë°superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëû0ùëÑ1~‚àásubscriptùëìsubscriptùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùë§subscriptùëñùë°ùëûŒ©ùë°21ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscript~ùëîùëñùë°2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i_{t}}\left[S_{a_{2}}\right]=\mathbb{E}_{i_{t}}\left\lVert\sum\limits_{q=0}^{Q{-}1}\tilde{\nabla}f_{i_{t}}\left(w_{i_{t},q}^{\Omega(t)}\right)\right\rVert^{2}=\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert\tilde{g}_{i}^{t}\right\rVert^{2}. (42)

Now, according to (35), (41), and (42), we have:

ùîº‚Äãf‚Äã(wt+1)ùîºùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°1\displaystyle\mathbb{E}f\left(w^{t{+}1}\right) ‚â§ùîº‚Äãf‚Äã(wt)‚àíŒ∑‚ÄãŒ≤‚Äã(2‚ÄãQ‚àí1)2‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚à•‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•2absentùîºùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°ùúÇùõΩ2ùëÑ12ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°2\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}f(w^{t})-\frac{\eta\beta(2Q{-}1)}{2}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla f(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2} (43)
+Œ∑‚ÄãŒ≤2‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚à•gt‚àíQ‚Äã‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•2‚èü=‚Å£:Sa3+L‚ÄãŒ∑2‚ÄãŒ≤22‚Äãn‚Äãùîº‚Äã[‚àëi=1n‚à•g~it‚à•2]‚èü=‚Å£:Sa4,ùúÇùõΩ2ùîºsubscript‚èüsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùëîùë°ùëÑ‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë§ùë°2:absentsubscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé3ùêøsuperscriptùúÇ2superscriptùõΩ22ùëõùîºsubscript‚èüdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscript~ùëîùëñùë°2:absentsubscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé4\displaystyle+\frac{\eta\beta}{2}\mathbb{E}\underbrace{\left\lVert g^{t}-Q\nabla f(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2}}_{=:S_{a_{3}}}+\frac{L\eta^{2}\beta^{2}}{2n}\mathbb{E}\underbrace{\left[\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert\tilde{g}_{i}^{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right]}_{=:S_{a_{4}}}, (44)

where we bound Sa3subscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé3S_{a_{3}} and Sa4subscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé4S_{a_{4}} as follows:

Sa3=‚à•1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n(git‚àíQ‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(wt))‚à•2subscriptùëÜsubscriptùëé3superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùë°ùëÑ‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùë§ùë°2\displaystyle S_{a_{3}}=\left\lVert\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left(g_{i}^{t}-Q\nabla f_{i}(w^{t})\right)\right\rVert^{2} ‚â§1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚à•git‚àíQ‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(wt)‚à•2absent1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùë°ùëÑ‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùë§ùë°2\displaystyle{\leq}\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert g_{i}^{t}-Q\nabla f_{i}(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2} (45)
